column3: Carl Linnaeus described a new system for classifying plants in Systema Naturae.
Ewald Georg von Kleist first capacitor, the Leyden jar.
Immanuel Kant: Gaseous Hypothesis in Universal Natural History and Theory of Heaven.
Mikhail Lomonosov: discovery of the atmosphere of Venus.
Thomas Bayes: publishes the first version of Bayes' theorem, paving the way for Bayesian probability.
Charles Messier: publishes catalogue of astronomical objects (Messier Objects) now known to include galaxies, star clusters, and nebulae.
Antoine Lavoisier (and Joseph Priestley): discovery of oxygen leading to end of Phlogiston theory.
William Herschel announces discovery of Uranus, expanding the known boundaries of the Solar System for the first time in modern history.
William Withering: publishes the first definitive account of the use of foxglove (digitalis) for treating dropsy.
Jacques Charles: Charles's law of ideal gases.
Antoine Lavoisier: law of conservation of mass, basis for chemistry, and the beginning of modern chemistry.
Georges Cuvier: Establishes extinction as a fact.
Alessandro Volta: discovers electrochemical series and invents the battery.
Hans Christian Ørsted discovers that a current passed through a wire will deflect the needle of a compass, establishing the deep relationship between electricity and magnetism (electromagnetism).
Michael Faraday and James Stoddart discover alloying iron with chromium produces a stainless steel resistant to oxidising elements (rust).
Thomas Johann Seebeck is the first to observe a property of semiconductors.[citation needed]

column4: Sadi Carnot, James Prescott Joule, Rudolf Clausius
Joseph Fourier, John Tyndall, and Svante Arrhenius
Sadi Carnot, James Prescott Joule, Rudolf Clausius

column3: Carnot: described the Carnot cycle, the idealized heat engine.
Joseph Aspdin develops Portland cement (concrete), by heating ground limestone, clay and gypsum, in a kiln.
Évariste Galois development of group theory.
Friedrich Wöhler synthesized urea, refuting vitalism.
Anselme Payen isolates first enzyme, diastase.
Charles Babbage proposes a design for the construction of a Turing complete, general purpose Computer, to be called the Analytical Engine.
Matthias Schleiden: all plants are made of cells.
Friedrich Bessel: first successful measure of stellar parallax (to star 61 Cygni).
James Prescott Joule: Law of Conservation of energy (First law of thermodynamics), also 1847 – Helmholtz, Conservation of energy.
Johann Gottfried Galle and Heinrich Louis d'Arrest: discovery of Neptune.
George Boole: publishes The Mathematical Analysis of Logic, defining Boolean algebra; refined in his 1854 The Laws of Thought.

Robert Forester Mushet develops a process for the decarbonisation, and re-carbonisation of iron, through the addition of a calculated quantity of spiegeleisen, to produce cheap, consistently high quality steel.
Rudolf Virchow: cells can only arise from pre-existing cells.
Charles Darwin and Alfred Wallace: Theory of evolution by natural selection.
John Tyndall:  Experiments in Radiant Energy that reinforced the Greenhouse effect.
James Clerk Maxwell: Theory of electromagnetism.
Gregor Mendel: Mendel's laws of inheritance, basis for genetics.
Robert Forester Mushet discovers that alloying steel with tungsten produces a harder, more durable alloy.
Lord Rayleigh: Diffuse sky radiation (Rayleigh scattering) explains why sky appears blue.
Johannes Diderik van der Waals: was one of the first to postulate an intermolecular force: the van der Waals force.
William Crookes invented the Crookes tube and studied cathode rays.
Josiah Willard Gibbs founded chemical thermodynamics, the phase rule.
Ludwig Boltzmann: Statistical definition of entropy.

John Hopkinson develops three-phase electrical supplies, mathematically proves how multiple AC dynamos can be connected in parallel, improves permanent magnets, and dynamo efficiency, by the addition of tungsten, and describes how temperature effects magnetism (Hopkinson effect).
Pierre Curie and Jacques Curie: Piezoelectricity.
Jacobus Henricus van 't Hoff: discovered the laws of chemical dynamics and osmotic pressure in solutions (in his work "Études de dynamique chimique").
Albert A. Michelson and Edward W. Morley: Michelson–Morley experiment which showed a lack of evidence for the aether.

column4: Marie Curie, Pierre Curie, and Henri Becquerel
Marie Curie, Pierre Curie, and Henri Becquerel

column3: Svante Arrhenius derives the basic principles of the greenhouse effect
J.J. Thomson discovers the electron in cathode rays
Martinus Beijerinck: concluded that a virus is infectious—replicating in the host—and thus not a mere toxin, and gave it the name "virus"
J.J. Thomson proposed the plum pudding model of an atom
Marie Curie discovered radium and polonium
J. J. O'Donnell discovers and documents the order-of-sequence for the sound of an approaching tornado

column4: Max Planck, Albert Einstein, Werner Heisenberg, Erwin Schrödinger and others
Max Planck, Werner Heisenberg, Erwin Schrödinger, Paul Dirac
Max Planck, Albert Einstein, Werner Heisenberg, Erwin Schrödinger and others
Max Planck, Werner Heisenberg, Erwin Schrödinger, Paul Dirac

column3: Max Planck: explains the emission spectrum of a black body

column4: The Wright brothers (Orville and Wilbur Wright)
The Wright brothers (Orville and Wilbur Wright)

column3: Albert Einstein: theory of special relativity, explanation of Brownian motion, and photoelectric effect
Walther Nernst: Third law of thermodynamics
Alfred Bertheim: Arsphenamine, the first modern chemotherapeutic agent
Fritz Haber: Haber Process for industrial production of ammonia
Robert Andrews Millikan: conducts the oil drop experiment and determines the charge on an electron
Williamina Fleming: the first white dwarf, 40 Eridani B
Henrietta Swan Leavitt: Cepheid variable period-luminosity relation
Niels Bohr: Model of the atom
Albert Einstein: theory of general relativity – also David Hilbert
Karl Schwarzschild: discovery of the Schwarzschild radius leading to the identification of black holes
Emmy Noether: Noether's theorem – conditions under which the conservation laws are valid

column4: Dr. Albert H. Taylor & Leo C. Young

Herbert McLean Evans & Katherine Scott
Bishop

column3: Frederick Banting, Charles Best, James Collip, John Macleod: isolation and production of insulin to control diabetes
Wolfgang Pauli: quantum Pauli exclusion principle
Edwin Hubble: the discovery that the Milky Way is just one of many galaxies
Cecilia Payne-Gaposchkin: Discovery of the composition of the Sun and that hydrogen is the most abundant element in the Universe
Georges Lemaître: Theory of the Big Bang
Edwin Hubble: Hubble's law of the expanding universe
Alexander Fleming: Penicillin, the first beta-lactam antibiotic
Lars Onsager's reciprocal relations, a potential fourth law of thermodynamics
Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar discovers his eponymous limit of the maximum mass of a white dwarf star
Kurt Gödel: incompleteness theorems prove formal axiomatic systems are incomplete
James Chadwick: Discovery of the neutron
Karl Guthe Jansky discovers the first astronomical radio source, Sagittarius A
Ernest Walton and John Cockcroft: Nuclear fission by proton bombardment
Enrico Fermi: Nuclear fission by neutron irradiation
Clive McCay: Calorie restriction extends the maximum lifespan of another species

column4: J. H. Oort and F. Zwicky
J. H. Oort and F. Zwicky

column3: Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner and Fritz Strassmann: Nuclear fission of heavy nuclei
Oswald Avery proves that DNA is the genetic material of the chromosome
Howard Florey Mass production of penicillin

column4: William Shockley, John Bardeen and Walter Brattain
William Shockley, John Bardeen and Walter Brattain

column3: William Shockley, John Bardeen and Walter Brattain invent the first transistor

column4:
John Bardeen, William Shockley & Walter
Brattain

column3: Claude Elwood Shannon: 'A mathematical theory of communication' a seminal paper in Information theory.
Richard Feynman, Julian Schwinger, Sin-Itiro Tomonaga and Freeman Dyson: Quantum electrodynamics
George Otto Gey propagates first cancer cell line, HeLa
Jonas Salk: developed and tested first polio vaccine
Stanley Miller: demonstrated that the building blocks of life could arise from primeval soup in the conditions present during early Earth (Miller-Urey experiment)
Frederick Sanger: demonstrated that proteins are sequences of amino acids
James Watson, Francis Crick, Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin: helical structure of DNA, basis for molecular biology

column4: John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Allen Newell and Herbert A. Simon
John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Allen Newell and Herbert A. Simon

column3: Chien Shiung Wu: demonstrated that parity, and thus charge conjugation and time-reversals, are violated for weak interactions
Riccardo Giacconi and his team discover the first cosmic x-ray source, Scorpius X-1
Lawrence Morley, Fred Vine, and Drummond Matthews:  Paleomagnetic stripes in ocean crust as evidence of plate tectonics (Vine–Matthews–Morley hypothesis).
Murray Gell-Mann and George Zweig: postulates quarks, leading to the standard model
Arno Penzias and Robert Woodrow Wilson: detection of CMBR providing experimental evidence for the Big Bang
Leonard Hayflick: normal cells divide only a certain number of times: the Hayflick limit
Jocelyn Bell Burnell and Antony Hewish discover first pulsar
Vela nuclear test detection satellites discover the first gamma-ray burst

James H. Ellis proposed the possibility of "non-secret encryption", more commonly termed public-key cryptography, a concept that would be implemented by his GCHQ colleague Clifford Cocks in 1973, in what would become known as the RSA algorithm, with key exchange added by a third colleague Malcolm J. Williamson, in 1975.
Place cells in the brain are discovered by John O'Keefe
Russell Alan Hulse and Joseph Hooton Taylor, Jr. discover indirect evidence for gravitational wave radiation in the Hulse–Taylor binary
Frederick Sanger sequences the first DNA genome of an organism using Sanger sequencing

column4: Roger L. Easton, Ivan A. Getting and Bradford Parkinson
Roger L. Easton, Ivan A. Getting and Bradford Parkinson

column3: Klaus von Klitzing discovered the quantum Hall effect
Donald C. Backer et al. discover the first millisecond pulsar
Kary Mullis invents the polymerase chain reaction, a key discovery in molecular biology

column4: Joe Farman, Brian Gardiner, and Jonathan Shanklin
Joe Farman, Brian Gardiner, and Jonathan Shanklin

column3: Karl Müller and Johannes Bednorz: Discovery of High-temperature superconductivity
Bart van Wees [nl] and colleagues at TU Delft and Philips Research discovered the quantized conductance in a two-dimensional electron gas.

column4: Tim Berners Lee with Robert Cailliau

column3: Mary-Claire King discovers the link between heritable breast cancers and a gene found on chromosome 17q21.[128][129]
Aleksander Wolszczan and Dale Frail observe the first pulsar planets (this was the first confirmed discovery of planets outside the Solar System)
Andrew Wiles proves Fermat's Last Theorem
Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz definitively observe the first extrasolar planet around a main sequence star
Eric Cornell, Carl Wieman and Wolfgang Ketterle attained the first Bose-Einstein Condensate with atomic gases, so called fifth state of matter at an extremely low temperature.
Roslin Institute: Dolly the sheep was cloned.[130]
CDF and DØ experiments at Fermilab: Top quark.

column4: Saul Perlmutter, Brian P. Schmidt, and Adam G. Riess
Saul Perlmutter, Brian P. Schmidt, and Adam G. Riess

column3: Supernova Cosmology Project and the High-Z Supernova Search Team: discovery of the accelerated expansion of the Universe and dark energy
The Tau neutrino is discovered by the DONUT collaboration
The first draft of the Human Genome Project is published.[131]
Grigori Perelman presents proof of the Poincaré Conjecture.
The Human Genome Project sequences the human genome with a 92% accuracy.[132]
Ben Green and Terence Tao announce their proof on arithmetic progressions in prime numbers known as the Green–Tao Theorem.
Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov isolated graphene, a monolayer of carbon atoms, and studied its quantum electrical properties.
Grid cells in the brain are discovered by Edvard Moser and May-Britt Moser.
The first self-replicating, synthetic bacterial cells are constructed.[133]

The Neanderthal Genome Project presented preliminary genetic evidence that interbreeding likely occurred and that a small but significant portion of Neanderthal admixture is present in modern non-African populations.[134]
Higgs boson is discovered at CERN (confirmed to 99.999% certainty)
Photonic molecules are discovered at MIT
Exotic hadrons are discovered at the LHCb
Photonic metamaterials are discovered to make passive daytime radiative cooling possible by Raman et al.[135][136]
The LIGO team detects gravitational waves from a black hole merger

Gravitational wave signal GW170817 is observed by the LIGO/Virgo collaboration. This is the first instance of a gravitational wave event observed to have a simultaneous electromagnetic signal when space telescopes like Hubble observed lights coming from the event, thereby marking a significant breakthrough for multi-messenger astronomy.[137][138][139]
The first image of a black hole is captured, using eight different telescopes taking simultaneous pictures, timed with extremely precise atomic clocks. [1]
NASA and SOFIA (Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy) discover about 12 US fl oz (350 ml) of surface water in one of the Moon's largest visible craters.[140]
The standard reference gene, GRCh38.p14, of the human genome, is fully sequenced and contains 3.1 billion base pairs.[141]
